instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
One of the charging port not working doesn't turn on ammeter at all.
I found UF400 is the corresponding <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> for the port..i replaced it and DF622 still no changes..
Now i just found DZF664 has a hole in it i changed it too still no changes..
I compared diode mode readings of <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> to good board values are ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings between USB-C ports for more test points.
Start checking CC1/2 lines.

Be sure FF200 is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
faulty board
<SIGNAL>USBC0_CC1</SIGNAL>=0.588
<SIGNAL>USBC0_CC2</SIGNAL>=0.586
<SIGNAL>USBC0_SBU1</SIGNAL>=665
Good board
<SIGNAL>USBC0_CC1</SIGNAL>=0.598
<SIGNAL>USBC0_CC2</SIGNAL>=0.593
<SIGNAL>USBC0_SBU1</SIGNAL>=0.666
FF201 and FF200 is good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
I dont know what just happened 
The board just powered on with battery only.
Draws 5v with charger only with both ports now.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is 12.06V with charger only 
12.60 with charger and battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
So the board works with battery alone, or battery plus charger?

One USB-C port still black screen on meter?
You should compare diode mode readings on the JF600 lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
The board works with battery alone..
Both ports display on the ammeter now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: I have compared JF600 line with working board no difference

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
with the board alone on desk,both USBC ports draws 5V 0.20mA at the ammeter 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is 12.03V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_SMC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> voltage; compare with good board.

You can try DFU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message:
Try wire method with SV004/5 pads.
Solder RV005, if is not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>
threads.message: How will i do that please?..
